question: Which process must occur for sediments to form a new rock in the rock cycle?

content.source_1: Metamorphic rock forms through metamorphism, a solid-state process in which existing minerals recrystallize under heat and/or pressure; without recrystallization, a rock is not considered metamorphic.
content.source_2: Many metamorphic rocks originate from sedimentary precursors (for example, shale can metamorphose into slate and then schist), so when sediments ultimately become metamorphic rock, that transformation requires recrystallization.
content.source_3: Sediments can become rock by lithification—compaction and cementation at low temperature and pressure—without undergoing metamorphic recrystallization.
content.source_4: The mineral cement that binds sediment grains precipitates from pore fluids; this precipitation is distinct from the solid-state recrystallization characteristic of metamorphism.
content.source_5: When sediments lithify into sedimentary rock, they have formed a new rock type; sedimentary rock is one of the three major rock classes.
content.source_6: Many sedimentary rocks (e.g., sandstone and shale) preserve original grain textures, demonstrating that no recrystallization was necessary for those sediments to form rock.
